NEWS BITES

Australia’s Record-Low Interest-Rate Cut Prompts Mixed Reviews Australia’s Reserve Bank’s move to lower interest rates to 0.75% after making cuts in June, July and August is causing concerns that the record-low rate may undermine the strong market, said Real Estate Institute of Queensland chief executive Antonia Mercorella. Although the cut will make it easier for Queenslanders to pay mortgages, when the rate drops below 1%, consumer confidence can also drop. Realestate.com.au

Singapore’s Rise in Private Home Prices Sparks Debate About Cooling Measures The private home price index in Singapore has risen for two straight quarters, according to the Urban Redevelopment Authority, and Barclays’ regional economist Brian Tan thinks the government could act quickly by instilling new market cooling measures. However, Mr. Tan believes the rise in home prices might just be reflecting an improvement in market sentiment. Business Times

Irish Developers Set Up Shop in Hong Kong to Field Immigration Inquiries Irish property developer Bartra Capital has responded to the record-high immigration inquiries from Hong Kong residents by setting up shop in the city, according to James Hartshorn, director of Asia at Bartra. Dublin created four options within the Immigrant Investor Programme to offer investment choices for those who want to reside and work in Ireland. South China Morning Post

U.K. Housing Secretary Announced Plans for Green Housing Revolution As the U.K. government strives for a net-zero emissions target, all newly built U.K. homes will follow rules under a new green standard to reduce emissions, according to Housing Secretary Robert Jenrick. U.K.homes now account for 20% of greenhouse gas emissions, and the Future Homes Standard will ban gas boilers in favor of clean technology. PropertyWire
